column1: Mankato ( man-KAY-toh) is a city in Blue Earth
column2: Nicollet
column3: and Le Sueur counties in the state of Minnesota. The population was 39
column4: 309 according to the 2010 census
column5: making it the fifth largest city in Minnesota outside the Minneapolis–Saint Paul metropolitan area. It is along a large bend of the Minnesota River at its confluence with the Blue Earth River. Mankato is across the Minnesota River from North Mankato. Mankato and North Mankato have a combined population of over 56
column6: 500 according to the 2018 census estimates. It completely encompasses the town of Skyline. North of Mankato Regional Airport
column7: a tiny non-contiguous part of the city lies within Le Sueur County. Most of the city is in Blue Earth County.

column1: Mankato is the larger of the two principal cities of the Mankato-North Mankato metropolitan area
column2: which covers Blue Earth and Nicollet counties and had a combined population of 94
column3: 149 at the 2010 census. The 2018 Census estimate is 101
column4: 647. The U.S. Census Bureau designated Mankato a Metropolitan Statistical Area in November 2008.In 2017

column1: The area was long settled by various cultures of indigenous peoples. After European colonization began on the East Coast
column2: pressure from settlement and other Native American tribes caused various peoples to migrate into the area. By the mid-19th century
column3: four Dakota language–speaking divisions of the Dakota Sioux were the primary indigenous group.

column1: Mankato Township was not settled by European Americans until Parsons King Johnson in February 1852
column2: as part of the 19th-century migration of people from the east across the Midwest. New residents organized the city of Mankato on May 11
column3: 1858. The city was organized by Henry Jackson
column4: Parsons King Johnson
column7: and others. A popular story says that the city was supposed to have been named Mahkato
column8: but a typographical error by a clerk established the name as Mankato. According to Warren Upham
column9: quoting historian Thomas Hughes of Mankato
column10: "The honor of christening the new city was accorded to Col. Robertson. He had taken the name from Nicollet's book
column11: in which the French explorer compared the 'Mahkato" or Blue Earth River
column13: to the water nymphs and their uncle in the German legend of Undine.'...No more appropriate name could be given the new city
column14: than that of the noble river at whose mouth it is located." While it is uncertain that the city was intended to be called Mahkato
column15: the Dakota called the river Makato Osa Watapa (meaning "the river where blue earth is gathered"). The Anglo settlers adapted that as "Blue Earth River". According to Frederick Webb Hodge
column16: in his Handbook of American Indians North of Mexico
column19: the town was named after the older of the two like-named chiefs of the Mdewakanton division of the Santee Dakota
column20: whose village stood on or near the site of the present town.

column2: also known as Chief Sleepy Eye
column3: of the Sisseton band of Dakota Indians

column3: the US Army carried out the largest mass execution in U.S. history at Mankato following the Dakota War of 1862. Thirty-eight Dakota Native Americans were hanged for their parts in the uprising. A military tribunal had sentenced 303 to death
column4: but President Lincoln reviewed the record and pardoned 265
column5: believing they had been involved in legitimate defense against military forces. Episcopal Bishop Henry Benjamin Whipple had urged leniency in the case
column6: but his position was not politically popular in Minnesota
column7: nor was Lincoln's intervention. Two commemorative statues stand on the site of the hangings (now home to the Blue Earth County Library and Reconciliation Park).

column1: Mankato was the basis for Deep Valley in Maud Hart Lovelace's Betsy-Tacy series of children's books and novels. The children/young adult wing of the Blue Earth County Library is named in her honor.
In Sinclair Lewis's 1920 novel Main Street
column2: heroine Carol Milford is a former Mankato resident. Lewis describes Mankato as follows: "In its garden-sheltered streets and aisles of elms is white and green New England reborn"
column3: alluding to its many migrants from New England
column4: who brought their culture with them. Lewis wrote a substantial portion of the novel while staying at the J.W. Schmidt House at 315 South Broad Street
column5: as now marked by a small plaque in front of the building.In the Little House on the Prairie television series
column6: Mankato is a trading town that the citizens of Walnut Grove visit. It does not appear in the Laura Ingalls Wilder books.

column1: Mankato has a humid continental climate

column3: with snow cover (continuous most winter seasons) beginning typically between mid-November and mid-December
column4: ending in March most years. However
column5: Mankato often receives less snow than areas to its north and east. For example
column8: averages over 54 inches or 1.37 metres of snow per winter season

column1: Minnesota State University was opened as the second state normal school in 1868 and is the second largest university in the state of Minnesota by enrollment. With an annual operating budget of over $200 million
column2: Minnesota State provides a net economic benefit of over $452 million annually to Minnesota's south-central region. It is one of the largest employers in the Mankato area.

column1: Minnesota State University was home to the Minnesota Vikings summer training camp for 52 years. The Vikings announced their training camp would move to Eagan starting in 2018.

Public transportation in Mankato is provided by the Mankato Transit System. The city is served by Mankato Regional Airport which has no commercial flights. Under MnDOT's 2015 State Rail Plan
column2: Mankato is listed as a Tier 1 Corridor for regional rail service from Minneapolis and/or St. Paul. U.S. Highways 14 and 169 and Minnesota State Highways 22 and 60 are four of the main routes in Mankato.
